US PROTECTIONIST COMMENTARY: ‘America First’ sparks fears of trade wars

In pre-market trade, US Secretary Mnuchin, speaking from Davos, received attention when he said that a weaker US dollar was good for US trade, which heaped pressure on the buck. He also added that he was not concerned by reports that China was considering easing its purchases of US Treasuries.

Following Mnuchin’s comments, Commerce Secretary Ross, also speaking from Davos, said US authorities were investigating whether there is scope to take action against China for intellectual property infringements, arguing that its technology policies were a “direct threat” to the US, giving rise to fears of a full-blown trade war between the two nations.

EQUITIES: SPX -0.1% at 2838, NDX -0.6% at 6919, DJI +0.2% at 26265
Top sectors: Telecom +0.7%, Financials +0.7%, Consumer Discretionary +0.4%
Bottom sectors: IT -0.9%, Utilities -0.6%, Energy -0.2%

Protectionist messages from US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and Commerce Secretary Ross at Davos soured equity traders sentiment in pre-market trade, and major equity indices tumbled on the cash open.

Additionally, a few bank equity research desks published analysis suggesting that pension companies will have to sell down their US equity holdings heading into month-end to ensure appropriate asset allocation. According to ZeroHedge, Goldman Sachs calculates the larest equity sell imbalance since 1995, with $34.4bln for sale; Morgan Stanley’s model expects $70bln of outflows from equities (and $62bln inflows into fixed income), while Credit Suisse also released similar research.

US shares came under further pressure after a 5-year auction tailed, despite slightly better cover demand. But after the post-auction selling, the ever-reliable buy-the-dip traders emerged, sending bourses back to flat levels.

Some profit taking after a run of record highs was also cited for the selling pressure.


TREASURIES: US 10-Year T-Note futures settle 7 ticks lower at 122-06+

Treasury prices fell on Wednesday after US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin endorsed a weak US dollar, resulting in the curve bear steepening. The steeper curve contributed to some modest widening of curve spreads (2s30s was slightly wider, as was 5s30s at settlement), however, 2s5s and 2s10s saw some (again, modest) narrowing.

The US auctioned $34bln of 5-year notes in an average sale, tailing by 0.4bps despite better cover than the prior auction. Internals were mostly in-line with recent averages, though the auction was, perhaps, not as bad as some had feared given today’s steeper Treasury curve.

FX

FOREX: USD slammed after Mnuchin welcomes weakness

 

Wednesday’s dollar weakness was inspired from protectionist rhetoric from the US Treasury Secretary in Davos, where he welcomed the buck’s weakness, arguing that it was positive for trade, seemingly abandoning the long-held US position of a strong USD. The result was the Dollar Index falling to three-year lows, while the yen strength continues, sending USDJPY to 109.00.

The greenback’s weakness flattered other FX, with the EUR continuing its ascent ahead of tomorrow’s ECB, topping 1.24 against the dollar. Separately, the latest batch of PMI data show that, despite weakness in manufacturing, composite PMIs are now at 12-year highs.

The pound, meanwhile, took advantage of the dollar weakness to trade above 1.42, helped along by a decent labour market report which showed wages rising more than expected (though still remain in negative real growth)(. EURGBP seems to be finding it a challenge to breach 0.87, however.

BRL got a boost after all three Brazil appeal court judges uphold former President Lula corruption conviction, in a blow to his political comeback.

Gold continued its assent on USD weakness, trading above $1360 at one point, while USDCHF fell beneath the 0.95 mark.
 

COMMODITIES

WTI futures settle $1.14 higher at $65.61 per barrel; Brent futures settle 57 cents higher $70.53 per barrel

Crude firmed on Wednesday after EIA data showed that crude stocks drew down in the week. Some had expect a build after the API on Tuesday reported stocks had gained in the week. Crude production, meanwhile, rose by 1.3% to 9.878mln barrels per day.

Crude also was supported by a weaker dollar, and the result was the backwardation between the front-month and the second month widened to 29 cents, the largest since October 2014.

Wednesday’s jawboning was predominantly provided by the Saudi energy minister and his Russian counterpart. The former said that he is still expecting the oil market to rebalance by Q3 2018, and argued that US shale output was not a threat to the market dynamics since higher production in the US was being offset by shrinking supplies in Mexico and Venezuela. The Saudi Energy minister warned, however, that a glut could return if the market was out of balance “for a few months”, and added that it was unlikely that the supply cut policy will be exited in June.

The Russian energy minister’s comments were in a similar vein, striking a unified position with his Saudi counterpart.

Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih says US oil boom is not a threat as Mexico and Venezuela output is declining, also says he doesn’t see any signs of significant slowing in oil demand. He added that the oil glut could return if the market is out of balance for a few months, and as a result it is highly unlikely that we will exit cuts in June. He also stated that there will be a moment when the production cuts can be adjusted and that producers will have to decide on a new inventory target and discuss slow exit from the deal so markets aren’t shocked. PRIMER: The bank desks weigh in on New Zealand's Q4 CPI release, due at 21:45 GMT
content:
ANZ: We expect headline CPI inflation to hold steady at 1.9% y/y in Q4. That is a touch above the RBNZ’s expectations. Some of the more volatile components (food, petrol and airfares) will make broadly offsetting contributions. Housing will again contribute positively, but evidence of a broadening in domestic price increases will remain tentative at best. Core inflation measures are likely to be stable around 1½-2%. We still expect domestic inflation to rise gradually in time. However, questions over when and how aggressively this occurs will likely remain unanswered by these figures, keeping the RBNZ side-lined.

ASB: We expect the CPI to print at 0.5% qoq in Q4 with annual CPI inflation firming to 2.0% (the second time annual inflation has reached at least 2% in the last year). This lift reflects of a number of one-off movements, rather than stronger underlying inflation. For example, the sharp jump in petrol prices over the quarter accounts for nearly half of the quarter’s lift in inflation. On top of that, the shift to updated CPI weightings added to Q4 inflation, at the margin. A contained backdrop for overall inflation should encourage a prolonged period of stability in OCR settings. The next move in the OCR is most likely to be up, but this still looks to be a 2019 story.

BNZ: We are in line with the market in expecting a 0.4% increase for the quarter, leaving annual inflation at 1.9%. The RBNZ, in its November Monetary Policy Statement, expected annual CPI inflation of 1.8% (based on 0.3% for the quarter). This involved non- tradables inflation decelerating to 2.4%, from 2.6% in Q3, and tradables inflation remaining at 1.0% y/y. It will also pay to check the range of “official” core inflation measures for Q4, especially the sectoral factor model version produced and favoured by the RBNZ, which, at 1.4% y/y in Q3, was obviously lagging the others. Providing the Q4 CPI doesn’t shock, the debate will turn to how the NZ CPI will print in the early stages of 2018. In particular, that there is a good chance its annual rate of inflation will slow in Q1 2018 – simply because a stocky quarterly result from Q1 2017 will be dropping out of the calculations. We expect CPI inflation to dip to 1.5% y/y in Q1, for instance, and stay there in Q2.

HSBC: We expect annual headline CPI inflation to lift slightly, with the major positive influence being a 6% rise in petrol prices seen in the quarter. Beyond that, inflation is likely to remain fairly subdued, with housing costs the only area of clear upward pressure. We expect a further modest lift in the measures of underlying inflation.

TD Securities: The new lower weight for fuel (8.7% to 6.4%) lowered our Q4 CPI forecast from +0.4% to +0.3%/q. Food we already know fell -1.6%/q (and has a higher weight at 19.3%). Housing is always robust, and fuel boosts Private transport by +3.5%/q. Expect a seasonal jump in airfares (Public transport +7.4%/q) and otherwise, health and education are neutral for the Dec quarter. We find ourselves at the dovish end of the market spectrum, but this is no way detracts from our view that the process-paralyzed RBNZ is increasingly behind the curve.

Westpac: We estimate that consumer prices rose by 0.4% in the December quarter, led by higher fuel prices and other transport costs. This would keep the annual inflation rate at 1.9%, very near the 2% midpoint of the Reserve Bank’s target range. Excluding the volatile food and fuel categories, we expect annual inflation to remain at a more modest 1.6%. Our forecast is slightly higher than the Reserve Bank’s pick of 0.3% for the quarter, although the difference is in the more persistent non–tradable categories where an upside surprise would be more significant. The December quarter release will incorporate Stat NZ’s Three - yearly reweighting of the basket of goods and services that make up the CPI. However, the new weights have had very little impact on our inflation forecast.

Preview: US 5-yr note & 2-yr FRN Auctions
content:
PREVIEW: US to sell USD 15bln 2-year FRN’s at 1630 GMT (1130 ET)

2-YEAR FRN AUCTION HISTORY:
- Discount Margin Previous 0.048%
- Bid-to-cover: Previous 3.26x
- Dealers: Previous 37.3%
- Directs/Indirects: Previous 62.7%   

PREVIEW: US to sell USD 34bln 5-year notes at 1800 GMT (1300 ET)

The US Treasury will sell a total of USD 103.0bln during the week, with USD 104.5bln set to mature at month-end.

Shorter dated Treasury yields have continued to move higher over the past month, and as a result TD Securities expect 5-year & 7-year coupons to be 25bps higher in this auction cycle compared with December’s.

It is also worth noting that CME Fed Fund Futures are pricing in just shy of a 75% chance of a 25bps Fed hike at its March meeting, with the same instrument currently pricing a 60% chance of 3 hikes this calendar year.

Last month’s shorter dated note auctions came in on the softer side, although the supply took place between Christmas and the turn of the year, and many expect the recent uptick in yields to garner extra demand in this cycle.

TD Securities look to the “recent cheapening of 5s on the curve and the rise in yields to attract added demand.”

Societe Generale suggest that the current 5-year note is trading cheap on asset swap terms versus old 5s, and is trading fair on the curve relative to the 2s and 10s. Overall, the bank is “slightly positive on the upcoming 5-year note auction, which seems to have a setup from a relative value perspective.” The bank also notes that the current 5-year is higher than any 5-year note auction yield since April 2010, which it identifies as a positive.

5-YEAR AUCTION HISTORY:
- High yield: Previous 2.245% (vs six-auction average of 1.984%)
- Tail size: Previous tailed by 1.8bps (vs six-auction average of 0.1bps tail)
- Bid-to-cover: Previous 2.36x (vs six-auction average of 2.49x)
- Dealers: Previous 33.7% (vs six-auction average of 24.8%)
- Directs: Previous 7.9% (vs six-auction average of 9.5%)
- Indirects: Previous 58.4% (vs six-auction average of 65.7%)

FX Daily Wrap: woeful Wednesday for already unwanted Dollar
content: The Usd sank to new 2018 and even longer lows against all major counterparts and more, with the broad selling intensified after comments from US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin acknowledging the trade benefits of a weaker currency. Even some back-tracking via Commerce Secretary Ross failed to really stem the tide and the last straw for the beleaguered Greenback came in the form of sub-forecast existing home sales. So called key, psychological and chart levels simply gave way amidst the waves of Dollar selling and the DXY is now looking at 0.8900 having only just grip of the 90.000 handle. For the record, next on the tech ‘support’ front is 88.921 and 88.510, but in the current situation these may be irrelevant. Indeed, Eur/Usd is close to 1.2400 having breezed through a supposed major Fib at 1.2377, and only the ECB meeting seems to be stalling more upside on the basis that President Draghi may attempt to talk the single currency back down. Cable is above 1.4200, Usd/Jpy on the brink of falling below 109.00 (109.07 another chart level perceived to be key) and Usd/Chf near 0.9400 (0.9421 is the 2017 base). The antipodeans are also benefiting from their namesake’s travails with Aud/Usd approaching 0.8100 (0.8125 is last year’s high) and Nzd/Usd around 0.7425 (very close to ‘resistance’ in the 0.7430-35 area) ahead of NZ CPI data tonight.

(Newswires / CNBC)

United Technologies Corp (UTX) Q4 EPS USD 1.60 vs. Exp. USD 1.56, revenue USD 15.7bln vs. Exp. USD 15.4bln, Sees FY Adj. EPS USD 6.85-7.10 vs. Exp. USD 7.38. (Newswires)

 

DJIA

Apple (AAPL) – Canalys say the tech giant shipped 29mln iPhone X’s in Q4 of 2017.  Separately, Apple say IOS 11.3 will deliver new ways to experience Augmented Reality on its iPhone and iPad, also its Apple Music is to start support music videos. Also, CNBC report the co. is moving deeper into health care with a new service, as it releases a new product which allows users to download their personal health records. (Newswires / CNBC)

Chevron Corp (CVX) – The co. could be subject to tighter emission restrictions at Wheatstone LNG in Western Australia, following the environmental review carried out by the state on the USD 34bln project. (Newswires)

General Electric Co (GE) – The co. seeks alternative structuring arrangements rather than a break-up of the economy according to Alec Burger, head of the aircraft finance unit. (Newswires)

Merck (MRK) – Inge Thulin, CEO of 3M (MMM) will join the company board March 1st, bringing the board to 14 members. (Newswires)

Pfizer (PFE) – The pharmaceutical giant announces top line results for potential biosimilar to Rituxan/Mabthera. (Newswires)

Verizon (VZ) – The communications co. acquires Movildata Internacional, Spain based provider of commercial fleet management solutions; financial terms not disclosed. (Newswires)

 

S&P 500

Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) – The chip maker has hired Mike Rayfield, a previous executive at Micron (MU) and Nvidia (NVDA), and David Wang who was previously at Synaptics (SYNA) for executive roles at its graphic chips unit, Radeon Technologies Group. (Venture Beat)

AT&T (T) / Facebook (FB) / Twitter (TWTR) – The CEO of AT&T is calling Congress to form a net neutrality law. (Recode)

CSX Corp. (CSX) – The co. is to require its CEO, to complete an annual physical health exam. (Newswires)

Kinder Morgan (KMI) –  Says it initiated a USD 2bln buyback in December 2017, which was a month ahead of its original target. The co. forecasts 3.2bln of growth projects in commercial service this year, it also expects to fund all investment needs other than its debt maturities with internal cash flow. Finally, The US Tax reform is to have a one-time, non-cash negative impact of USD 1.4bln to GAAP earnings. (Newswires)

Perrigo (PRGO) – The co. announced it received final FDA approval of the generic version of its Estrace Cream. (Newswires)

Valero (VLO) – The board of the co. has agreed to raise its quarterly dividend by 14%, and announced a further USD 2.5bln share repurchase authorisation. (Newswires)

Wells Fargo (WFC) – The bank raises its share buyback programme by 350mln shares. (Newswires)

 

NASDAQ 100

Amazon (AMZN) – The retailers web services acquired a cyber-security start up called Sqrrl; financial terms not disclosed. (Newswires)

Baidu (BIDU) – The co. is seeking new investors for its wholly owned finance unit which could reach up to USD 2bln and further the push into financial services, according to people familiar with the matter. (Newswires)

Facebook (FB) – The social media giant and ESL announced it will bring content from two of the top e-sports competitions to Facebook, also the social media giant purchased Confirm, which specialises in identification authentication technology; financial terms have not been disclosed. Separately, its head of AI research has stepped down to become chief AI Scientist. (Newswires / Quartz)

Qualcomm (QCOM) – EU Antitrust regulators are to fine Qualcomm for USD 1.2bln for paying Apple (AAPL) to only use its chips, Qualcomm announced it will be appealing this.  Further, the co. forecasts smartphone application processor shipments to decrease in 2018. (Newswires / Digitimes)

SiriusXM (SIRI) – The tech co.’s board approves authorisation to extend its share buyback programme by USD 2bln. (Newswires)

Starbucks (SBUX) – The coffee retailer is to boost worker pay and benefits after US lowers corporate taxes. (Newswires)

Tesla Inc (TSLA) – The auto maker does not believe solar tariff imposed by US President Trump will have much of an impact on its solar manufacturing plans, due to a clause exempting a vast number of solar panel parts from the tariff. (Newswires)

 

OTHER NEWS

ComScor (SCOR) – The co is looking at other options, and is working with Goldman Sachs regarding a potential sale. (Newswires)

Dr Reddy’s (RDY) – A German regulator re-inspected its Bachupally plant. (Newswires)

Embraer (ERJ) – Bombardier invoked the Jet manufacturer in the trade dispute with Boeing (BA). (Newswires)  

First Horizon National Corp. (FHN) – The bank holding company increases its quarterly dividend by 33%. (Newswires)

Microsemi (MSCC) – The co. is exploring its options, including a sale after it received a takeover offer. (Newswires)

Novartis (NVS) – The co. expects to return to operating profit growth this year, it noted operating growth would be in the high single digit percentage. (Newswires)

Puma Biotechnology (PBYI) – The co. said a European regulatory panel showed it was unlikely to provide a favourable opinion on the co.’s breast cancer drug. (Newswires)

Qiagen (QGEN) – The co.’s Jak2 test received clearance from the FDA. (Newswires)

Sandridge (SD) – The co. issued a letter to shareholders to accept Icahn’s proposal. (Newswires)

United Steel (X) – The steel producer is pleased with US President Trump’s tariffs on specific imports. (Newswires)

Universal Display Corporation (OLED) – The co. and Sharp Corp. (SHCAY) enter into an extended agreement. (Newswires)

PREVIEW: Norges Bank Monetary Policy Decision due on Thursday 25th January 2018
content:
Full pdf available here.

  • All of the 16 analysts surveyed by Reuters expect the Norges Bank to leave its policy rate unchanged at 0.50%.
  • The two major developments since the Norges Bank last convened are that interest rate expectations for other central banks have edged upwards, while oil prices have rallied.
  • Any language around the housing the market will be heavily scrutinised, and could provide the key point of interest at this decision.
  • All-in-all more focus is being placed on the March meeting, which will be accompanied by a fresh set of economic forecasts.

content: We think that for most BoE members, continuing job market strength supports the case for at least one more hike in Bank Rate (from 0.5% to 0.75%). We expect this in May 2018.

subject: Barclays on the UK labour market
content: Upside risk to rates outlook from low productivity, not low unemployment. With claimant count and monthly unemployment increasing, we continue to believe that the unemployment rate has reached a low at 4.3%. But as long as job creation remains as strong as in the latest print, any increase in unemployment will be limited. New jobs despite lower GDP growth will raise fresh doubts regarding the outlook for productivity and wages over the medium to long run. In other words, if productivity fails to recover in line with even the most cautious forecasts, wage growth at the current level would already be consistent with accelerating labour costs and might support further rate hikes by the BoE. Alternatively, as presented by MPC Ramsden, the rise in uncertainty may have triggered an increase in risk aversion from households who now prioritise jobs versus pay. In that case, job growth and pay weakness could persist as long as uncertainty prevails.

DAILY US OPENING NEWS: USD faces further pressure after US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin says the weaker dollar is good for trade
content:
• USD faces further pressure after US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin says the weaker dollar is good for trade
  • European bourses directionless, FTSE lags amid firmer GBP with GBP/USD briefly above 1.4100
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US services and manufacturing PMI, DoEs and NZ CPI

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mixed following an unconvincing close on Wall St. where all majors posted fresh record highs and the Nasdaq 100 outperformed as Netflix led post-earnings, although DJIA failed to hold onto gains and finished flat. ASX 200 (+0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.8%) were varied with Japanese exporter sentiment weighed by a firmer currency and following a miss on trade data. Elsewhere, a cautious tone was seen in Chinese markets with the Hang Seng (-0.1%) and the Shanghai Comp. (+0.3%) choppy alongside early weakness in Shenzhen, as ChiNext heavyweight Leshi Internet & Tech Co. returned from a 9-month trading halt to hit limit down with losses of 10% at the open. Finally, 10yr JGBs were range-bound as initial support from a risk averse tone was later pared, while the BoJ were also in the JGB market for between 1yr-10yr maturities with all the amounts of its Rinban operation kept unchanged.

PBoC injected CNY 110bln via 7-day, CNY 100bln via 14-day and CNY 10bln via 63-day reverse repos. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3916 (Prev. 6.4009)

Japanese Exports YY (Dec) 9.30% vs. Exp. 10.00% (Prev. 16.20%)

Japanese Imports YY (Dec) 14.90% vs. Exp. 12.40% (Prev. 17.20%)

EU/UK/US

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin says the weaker dollar is good for trade. (Newswires)

White House Economic Adviser Cohn says President Trump's message at Davos will be to invest in America, although that doesn't mean he is withdrawing US from the global trade scene. (Newswires)

US Senate voted 85 vs. 12 in favour of confirming Fed’s Powell as the next Fed Chair. (Newswires)

US Republican Senator Roberts said President Trump's trade policies are raising concerns within the Republican Party. (Newswires)

ECB's Draghi stated APP have not led to statistically significant euro exchange rate movements. (Newswires)

UK Conservative MPs tell PM May that UK must not be bound by EU rules during the Brexit transition period. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities (Eurostoxx 50 -0.1%) trade with little in the way of firm direction in the wake of what was a relatively mixed session during Asia-Pac trade. In terms of outliers from an index perspective, the FSTE 100 (-0.5%) lags its peers amid a firmer GBP and softness in Sage shares (-5.5%) after a disappointing earnings update. Looking at the sectors, health care names outperform their peers following the latest earnings update from Novartis (+2.4%), to the downside, utility names lag after Suez Environment (-17%) issued a profit warning, IT names are also seen lower with Infineon and STMicroelectronics near the foot of the DAX and CAC respectively.

FX

The USD has succumbed to yet more selling pressure, and right across the board as the Greenback’s losses stack up against G10 peers, EM currencies and commodities. The USD was dealt a further blow during European trade after US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin stated that the weaker USD is good for trade. The Index is below layered chart ‘supports’ under 90.000 and now looking at 89.370 to potentially arrest the slide before the next round number. In terms of USD pairings, the 110.00 handle vs JPY has given way and 109.56 ahead of 109.07 are now within sight, while Cable has extended post-Brexit vote highs above the 1.4000 level to around 1.4075 and briefly broke above 1.4100 following the latest jobs report with UK employment at a record high. EUR/USD has probed a bit further beyond 1.2300 to 1.2345, but displaying some caution ahead of tomorrow’s ECB meet and a Fib level at 1.2377. USD/CAD has dipped below 1.2400 amidst some constructive NAFTA noises after the 1st day of the latest round of talks and 1.2355 is the nearest support/recent low. USD/CHF has also breached its previous January base and 0.9500 is within sight, while AUD/USD and NZD/USD are both on track to post fresh year-to-date peaks.

FIXED INCOME

Gilts have lead the latest downturn in core debt, and knee-jerked below nearest chart support at 123.12 to a new Liffe low at 123.08, which suggests that the psychological 123.00 level will be next on the radar for bears. Similarly, the 1.40% cash yield is being tested on the back of some much better than anticipated elements of the latest UK jobs and earnings release. Bunds have been dragged down in sympathy and also through some near term tech levels on the way to a fresh 160.51 Eurex base, with Monday’s low now in sight. US Treasuries just off overnight troughs and awaiting more supply along with a busier data schedule, but bonds still relatively calm and rangebound in comparison to the action in FX markets where the USD continues to collapse.

COMMODITIES

WTI crude futures trade in close proximity to the lows seen yesterday in the wake of the latest API inventory report which showed an unexpected build in headline crude stockpiles. Elsewhere in energy newsflow, source reports suggest that Saudi Arabia intend on keeping their Q1 crude oil production at 9.8mln bpd and exports at around 7mln bpd, despite planned domestic refinery maintenance. In metals markets, despite being relatively rangebound overnight, gold has benefitted during European trade from the broad softness in the USD. Elsewhere copper nursed some of its recent losses during Asia-Pac trade amid touted short-covering.

PRIMER: The bank desks weigh in on the upcoming UK Labour Market Report, due at 09:30 GMT
content:
Barclays: We expect the unemployment rate to remain largely unchanged, reflecting increasing claimant counts and a marginally growing workforce. Meanwhile, we expect wages to grow at the same pace as the previous month (2.5%y/y for headline and 2.3% for core AWE).

Daiwa: The latest labour market data on Wednesday may show that employment continued falling towards the end of the year, by 25k in the three months to November, less than the 56k reduction in October. And given additional evidence that activity in the labour market is losing momentum, the headline unemployment rate is set to have remained unchanged at 4.3% for a fourth consecutive month, having fallen by 0.4ppt over the first half of 2017. Average earnings growth is expected to have remained at 2.5%3M/Y, below the rate of CPI inflation, and thus implying that real incomes continued to contract.

HSBC: Pay growth picked up a little in the three months to October, and we expect it to maintain its pace in the three months to November – albeit remaining some way below inflation. Unemployment was unchanged at 4.3%, its lowest since 1975 and the level at which it has stood since July 2017. That said, there were some early signs of job trends starting to turn, with employment down by 56k over the three months to October, and the claimant count rising for the third consecutive month in November. This, therefore may be the focus of the November release.

Nomura: Base effects (a reasonably large rise in monthly earnings a year ago) could hold back the annual rates of average wage growth in this report. Still, we expect the trend in earnings growth to generally be upwards over this year and expect it to end the year around 3% (a similar view to that expressed by MPC member Michael Saunders in a speech this week). Productivity growth will inevitably need to improve if wages are to perform better over a more prolonged period of time, of course. We see no change in the unemployment rate, currently standing at 4.3%.

RBC: Generally, the employment intentions surveys have been more upbeat than the actual ONS data in recent months. So whilst the survey evidence tells us it is too soon to get carried away with recent declines in the official measure of employment, it would represent a very strong outturn if the 3m/3m employment change recovered to a positive reading, after a decline of 56k last time. The arithmetic points to the unemployment rate holding at 4.3% this time. For average earnings we expect both the including- and excluding-bonus measures of growth to ease 0.1ppt to 2.4% 3m/y and 2.2% 3m/y, respectively. The more sensitive news for markets on pay growth is likely to come when the MPC update their expectations at the February Inflation Report in light of the regional agents’ annual pay settlements survey.

subject: Bunds: initial uptick quickly faded ahead of flash EZ PMIs
content: Another fleeting opening mark-up for the 10 year German benchmark bond, but rallies look increasingly half-hearted given healthy underlying fundamentals and bearish technicals. The Eurex range so far has been 160.66-85 vs yesterday’s 160.80 close and firmer than forecast preliminary PMIs from France, Germany and the Eurozone overall could push Bunds down further to test recent lows and key chart supports, like 160.30 and ultimately January’s 160.11 base. However, many market participants will be reluctant to test the extremes ahead of Thursday’s ECB policy meeting and broad consolidation within defined 2018 parameters to date could well pan out in the run up. Back to the charts, 161.13 was Tuesday’s intraday peak and some analysts are flagging 160.90 resistance based on hourly studies in the interim.

US futures were taking the lead from weakness in European markets before the cash open; however, as the cash trading day got underway, US bourses resumed their upwards march, underpinned by solid earnings aftermarket on Tuesday from Netflix, helping boost other FAANG names. However, a negative note on from JPMorgan regarding Apple iPhoneX demand weighed on the tech giants shares in afternoon trade, which also dragged on indices too.

Insurer Travelers reported earnings above expectations, helping it lead the Dow. Other earnings weren’t so bright: Johnson & Johnson and Procter & Gamble both pressured the Dow after their earnings.

There was also attention on steel names Alcoa and US Steel, with both trading higher after US President Trump said he was looking at applying tariffs on steel and aluminium imports. While Whirlpool and First Solar were trading firm after yesterday’s announcement that the US would impose tariffs on imports of solar panels and washing machines.

In terms of sectors, the defensive utilities were outperforming, closely followed by tech shares, while telecoms lagged. After market earnings highlights include Texas Instruments, and United Continental.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asian equity markets traded mixed with the Nikkei 225 lagging its peers amid a firmer JPY
content:
• Asian equity markets traded mixed with the Nikkei 225 lagging its peers amid a firmer JPY
  • In FX, USD woes persisted in which the DXY slipped to below 90.00 for the first time since late 2014
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Eurozone and US Manufacturing PMI, UK Jobs Report, DoEs and NZ CPI

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mixed following an unconvincing close on Wall St. where all majors posted fresh record highs and the Nasdaq 100 outperformed as Netflix led post-earnings, although DJIA failed to hold onto gains and finished flat. ASX 200 (+0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.7%) were varied with Japanese exporter sentiment weighed by a firmer currency and following a miss on trade data. Elsewhere, a cautious tone was seen in Chinese markets with mild profit taking in the Hang Seng (-0.1%) and the Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) was choppy alongside early weakness in Shenzhen, as ChiNext heavyweight Leshi Internet & Tech Co. returned from a 9-month trading halt to hit limit down with losses of 10% at the open. Finally, 10yr JGBs were range-bound as initial support from a risk averse tone was later pared, while the BoJ were also in the JGB market for between 1yr-10yr maturities with all the amounts of its Rinban operation kept unchanged.

PBoC injected CNY 110bln via 7-day, CNY 100bln via 14-day and CNY 10bln via 63-day reverse repos. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3916 (Prev. 6.4009)

Japanese Trade Balance Total Yen (Dec) 359.0B vs. Exp. 535.0B (Prev. 112.2B). (Newswires)
Japanese Exports YY (Dec) 9.30% vs. Exp. 10.00% (Prev. 16.20%)
Japanese Imports YY (Dec) 14.90% vs. Exp. 12.40% (Prev. 17.20%)

UK/EU

UK PM May reportedly faces backlash over claims in Brussels that the UK has agreed in principle to Norway-style transition period for Brexit, while other reports stated that UK Conservative MPs told PM May the UK must not be bound by EU rules during the Brexit transition period. (Newswires/Independent)

FX

USD woes persisted in which the DXY slipped to below 90.00 for the first time since late 2014. This underpinned its major counterparts with EUR/USD supported at 1.2300 and in which GBP/USD gained a firmer footing above 1.4000, while the PBoC also took a swipe and set a firmer reference rate of below 6.4000 for the first time since December 4th 2015. Elsewhere, a subdued risk tone facilitated flows into safe-haven JPY and alongside the underperformance in the greenback, resulted to a breakdown of the 110.00 handle for USD/JPY.

COMMODITIES

Commodities were relatively lacklustre in which WTI crude futures pared some of the prior day’s gains in late US trade after the latest API inventory report showed an unexpected build in headline crude stockpiles. Meanwhile, gold was flat but held near the prior day’s best levels amid further weakness in the greenback, and copper nursed some of its recent losses on short-covering.

US API weekly crude stocks (19 Jan, w/e) +4.755M vs. Exp. -1.600M (Prev. -5.120M). (Newswires)

Qatar’s energy minister sees oil market reaching balance by Q3 2018 and sees an excellent opportunity for OPEC and Non-OPEC to continue cooperation beyond 2018. (Newswires)


GEOPOLITICAL

US CIA Director Pompeo said that CIA believes North Korea weapons aimed at coercion and not just defense, while he also commented that US President Trump is focused on achieving a diplomatic solution regarding North Korea, although if this is not possible the CIA is working to provide Trump with a range of options to respond to the situation. (Newswires)

US

With President Trump in Davos, and a government shutdown potentially kicked down the road to 8/Feb, Treasury trade has been cautious, staying within recent ranges. The curve was narrower on the day, with yields in the belly falling by around c4.5bps on the day, while 10s were off by c4bps. The short end was bid ahead of the 2-year auction, which stopped through the screens by 0.1bps, and saw solid demand. With said government shutdown still looming in February, there was also attention on the four-week bill auction, which was also received well, stopping through by 2.5bps. The Treasury will auction 5s and a 2-year FRN tomorrow.  US T-Note futures (March) settles 10+ ticks higher at 122-13+.

US Senate voted 85 vs. 12 in favour of confirming Fed’s Powell as the next Fed Chair. (Newswires)

US President Trump said that they are looking at tariffs for steel and aluminium, while he separately commented that NAFTA negotiation talks are progressing well. (Newswires) US President Trump also tweeted overnight that 'Cryin Chuck Schumer fully understands, especially after his humiliating defeat, that if there is no Wall, there is no DACA. We must have safety and security, together with a strong Military'. (Twitter)

US Republican Senator Roberts said President Trump's trade policies are raising concerns within the Republican Party. (Newswires)

White House Economic Adviser Cohn said President Trump's message at Davos will be to invest in America, while he added that doesn't mean he is withdrawing US from the global trade scene. (Newswires)

US Special Counsel Mueller said he wants to question US President Trump over Comey. (Washington Post)
